column1: Wauwatosa (; originally Wau-wau-too-sa or Hart's Mill) is a city in Milwaukee County
column4: 396 at the 2010 census. Wauwatosa is located immediately west of Milwaukee
column5: and is a part of the Milwaukee metropolitan area. It is named after the Potawatomi Chief Wauwataesie and the Potawatomi word for firefly.

column1: The lush Menomonee Valley of the Wauwatosa area provided a key overland gateway between the rich glacial farmland of southeastern Wisconsin and the Port of Milwaukee. In 1835
column2: Charles Hart became the first Euro-American to settle here
column3: followed that year by 17 other families. The following year a United States Road was built from Milwaukee through Wauwatosa
column4: eventually reaching Madison. Charles Hart built a mill in 1845 on the Menomonee River which gave the settlement its original name of "Hart's Mill." The mill was torn down in 1914.The Town of Wau-wau-too-sa was created by act of the Wisconsin Territorial Legislature on April 30
column6: the population of the Town of Wau-wau-too-sa or Wauwatosa was 342. The town government was organized in 1842. The town's borders originally extended from the present-day Greenfield Avenue in the south to Hampton Avenue in the north
column7: and from 27th Street in the east to the Waukesha County line in the west
column10: plus the southern part of former North Milwaukee
column11: which was wholly annexed into the city of Milwaukee in 1927. Most of the town was farmland through the remainder of the 19th century.

column1: In 1849 the Watertown Plank Road was constructed through Wauwatosa
column2: mainly following the old Madison territorial road. In 1851 Wisconsin's first railroad (later The Milwaukee Road) established Wauwatosa as its western terminus. The Village of Wauwatosa was incorporated from the central part of the Town of Wauwatosa in 1892
column3: and was rechartered as the City of Wauwatosa on May 27
the City of Wauwatosa more than doubled its size by annexing 8.5 square miles (22 square kilometers) of land west of the Menomonee River
column4: the entire remaining portion of the Town of Wauwatosa
column5: which became the home to several large cold storage and regional food distribution terminals. Industrial plants owned by firms including Harley-Davidson and Briggs & Stratton were also constructed.

column2: western Wauwatosa has become an edge city with an important commercial and retail district built up along Milwaukee's beltline Highway 100 and anchored by the Mayfair Mall.

column1: Wauwatosa received some national attention in 1992 when the Wauwatosa Common Council
column3: decided to remove a Christian cross from the City's seal adopted in 1957. The cross was replaced with the text
column4: "In God We Trust." The seal itself was designed by 9-year old Suzanne Vallier as an entry in a contest among Wauwatosa schoolchildren. The quadrants of the logo's shield represent
column5: from top left going clockwise; an arrowhead representing the Indians who were the original inhabitants of the city
column6: the mill representing Hart's Mill which was the original name of the city
column7: the cross representing the "city of churches"
column8: and the symbol used on street signs representing the "city of homes."

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 13.25 square miles (34.32 km2)
column3: all land.Eastern Wauwatosa is also known for its homes and residential streets
column4: at one time just a short streetcar ride away from downtown Milwaukee. Prior to the arrival of Dutch elm disease
column5: many of Wauwatosa's older residential streets had large gothic colonnades of American Elm trees. In Wauwatosa
column6: the Menomonee Valley made it easier to quarry portions of the Niagara Escarpment
column7: which provided the necessary materials for sturdy
column9: limestone foundations used in many homes and public buildings throughout the region.

column1: The median age in the city was 39.8 years. 21.9% of residents were under the age of 18; 5.8% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 28.9% were from 25 to 44; 26.7% were from 45 to 64; and 16.6% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 46.6% male and 53.4% female.
Wauwatosa has a mayor–council government. The mayor is elected to a four-year term.
The Common Council is composed of 16 aldermen
column2: two from each of eight districts. They serve four-year terms
column3: with one member from each district up for election every other year. The aldermen set policy and have extensive financial control
column4: but are not engaged in daily operational management.

column1: Wauwatosa voters have supported both Democratic and Republican candidates.
Wauwatosa is served by the Wauwatosa School District:

Additional school-district services are provided to juvenile residents of the Milwaukee County Grounds—at Children's Hospital of Wisconsin and the Milwaukee County's Children and Adolescent Services Center—through the River Hills School on the Milwaukee County Mental Health Complex grounds. County juveniles in secure detention receive educational services through the Vel R. Phillips Juvenile Justice Center School within the Milwaukee County Children's Court buildingCatholic elementary schools in the city include Wauwatosa Catholic
Lutheran Schools include Our Redeemer and St. John's.
Wauwatosa contains Milwaukee County's Regional Medical Center
column2: which includes the Medical College of Wisconsin
column5: one of two level-one trauma centers in the state. Other points of interest are the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church designed by Frank Lloyd Wright; and the Memorial Center
column9: and the city hall. The Washington Highlands Historic District
column10: a residential neighborhood designed in 1916 by renowned city planner Werner Hegemann
column11: was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1989
column12: as was the Kneeland-Walker House. The Milwaukee County School of Agriculture and Domestic Economy Historic District
column13: located on a former high school campus
column14: was added in 1998. Other buildings on the list include Wauwatosa's oldest house
column15: the Lowell Damon House; the Thomas B. Hart House; and the Wauwatosa Woman's Club Clubhouse.

column2: the Tourism Commission of Wauwatosa sponsored the installation of several new murals by professional artists. ' The murals are curated by Milwaukee-based public arts agency Wallpapered City
column3: and the artworks appear on buildings from 64th Street to 70th Street along North Avenue.'

column1: Wauwatosa is the home town of the narrator of an unrecorded song by Bob Dylan
column3: Wisconsin" (not to be confused with the University of Wisconsin fight song of the same name).  The lyrics were written by Dylan in 1961 and finished in 2018 by local musician Trapper Schoepp.  Schoepp wrote music to accompany Dylan's lyrics and recorded the song at Wauwatosa's Wire & Vice studio for his album Primetime Illusion.
